name: Aburukuwa
description: A small membranophone played with sticks. It plays the role of a signal drum in the Kete ensemble.

name: Adawura
description: A non-melodic idiophone bell; Akan name for boat shaped bell bearing a striking resemblance to the Eʋe atoke.

name: Apentemma
description: A small, single-head, membranophone (smaller version of the Ɔperenten). It serves as an ensemble intermediary drum in various Akan settings, especially in the Adowa ensemble.

name: Ɔperenten
description: A single-head membranophone that serves as an ensemble intermediary drum in various Akan settings, especially Adowa ensemble.

name: Atumpan
description: Pair of single-headed membranophones used across West Africa for playing speech texts.

name: Donno
description: A double-headed hourglass drum played under the armpit with a stick. It serves a similiar function as the Luƞa.

name: Kwadum
description: A single-head membranophone and the master or lead drum in the Kete ensemble.

name: Nntorowa
description: A non-melodic idiophone shaker; embellishes the kete dawuro.

name: Petia
description: A single-head membranophone and the smallest drum in the Adowa ensemble.

name: Guƞgoƞ
description: A large cylindrical laced double-headed membranophone played in most Dagbama ensembles.

name: Kalamboo
description: A transverse aerophone made from cane consisting of four tone holes.

name: Luƞa
description: A double-headed hourglass drum played under the armpit with a stick.

name: Saɣyelim
description: A pair of woven basket shakers.

name: Atswereshie
description: A single-headed drum, conga-like in appearance. This drum symbolzied a new era of music and drumming as it was invented following the independence of Ghana. Also known as kpanlogo drum or kpanlogo mii.

name: Dodompo
description: A small finger bell or castanet.

name: Gome
description: A single-headed box drum.

name: Maracas
description: Non-melodic idiophones often created from gourds with beads inside. The appropriation of Cuban, Venzuelan, or Guatamalen maracas is common.

name: Ƞono
description: A large bell used to provide the rhythmic framework for the ensemble.

name: Shekeshe
description: A large gourd with beads around the outside, embellishes the rhythmic figure of the Ƞono.

name: Akaye
description: A non-melodic idiophone gourd shaker. Beads or seeds are inside the hollowed gourd. The instrument is excusively played by Women in all Northern Eʋe musical settings.

name: Asiʋui
description: A single headed membranophone. The Asiʋui is the lead drum in the Northern Eʋe ensemble.

name: Gakogoe
description: Double bell instrument, foundational for establishing the Eʋe clave pattern in most, if not all, ensembles. (Gakogui -  S. Eʋe)

name: Gakpeve
description: Double bell instrument, foundational for establishing the Eʋe clave pattern in most, if not all, ensembles. (Gakogui -  S. Eʋe, Gakogoe -  N. Eʋe)

name: Kretsiwa
description: A non-melodic idiophone finger-bell castanet.

name: Krokoto
description: A ceremonial single-headed membranophone performed by chiefs, hunters, and warriors. It is used as a speech surrogate and signal drum.

name: Lãdzo (ae)
description: The horn of an antelope or other large game. Reserved solely for the chief, the instrument is played by blowing air across an opening.

name: Lãdzo (id)
description: Smaller horns from an antelope or other large game are used as percussive block accompaniment to the Gakogoe.

name: Mba
description: Wooden clappers made from bamboo.

name: Uuvi
description: Secondary lead drum in the Eʋe ensemble. Will communicate with and accompany the Asiʋui.

name: Ʋugã
description: A single-head membranophone lead drum in the Bɔbɔɔbɔ ensemble

name: Agblɔʋu
description: Speech surrogate as well as a supporting drum in many Eʋe ensembles.

name: Atoke
description: A non-melodic, boat-shaped idiophone bell. The atoke is used to embellish and assist the role of the gakogui.

name: Atopani
description: A single head membranophone, originally from Akan origin, that is mostly used inside the court of chiefs.

name: Atsimeʋu
description: A single head membranophone and the largest drum in the Eʋe ensemble. It primarily serves as the lead drum

name: Axatse
description: A beaded gourd idiophone that embelleshes the gakogui rhythmic figure.

name: Gakogui
description: Double bell instrument, foundational for establishing the Eʋe clave pattern in most, if not all, ensembles. (Gakogoe -  N. Eʋe)

name: Gboba
description: A large single-headed membranophone used primarily in the Kinky and Gahu dances.

name: Kagan
description: A single-headed membranophone. The smallest and highest pitched drum in the Eʋe ensemble. The "child" drum

name: Kidi
description: A single headed membranophone, having all the featurs of the Sogo but smaller. It doubles the Sogo or partakes in dialogue with the Sogo. The "mother" drum.

name: Kroboto
description: A large single-headed membranophone used as a war drum.

name: Sogo
description: A single-headed membranophone literally meaning father drum. Functions as a leader to Kidi and Kagan drums.

name: Taʋugã
description: A single-headed membranophone reserved for politcal events and draped in white cloth to symbolize purity.
